title: evie-smith-starts-candles-soaps-business-bonnie-melts-lockdown
story: Evie Smith, , an S pupil at Musselburgh Grammar School, set up Bonnie Melts, making her own candles and soap based at her home.She said: ldquoI did not have much luck looking for a part-time job during national lockdown I knew I was not going to get a stable job in the current climate.ldquoI had applied for multiple jobs and, realising the marketplace was too competitive, I decided to start my own business.ldquoI started making candles at first and then soap.ldquoI started properly at the beginning of September after researching all the safety and labelling requirements and, within a week, I had earned enough to cover my start-up costs.ldquoItrsquos going great. I have nearly  followers on the Bonnie Melts Facebook page. It has become even busier in the run-up to Christmas. I am delivering every weekend and it is definitely keeping me busy.Evie was keen to have a Scottish name for her new venture, so decided on Bonnie Melts and currently sells her products via Facebook.She added: ldquoI was hoping when I set up there would be Christmas craft fairs but the current pandemic means online sales only. Deliveries are throughout Edinburgh and the Lothians, and I post within the UK too.Evie produces handmade eco-friendly scented and unscented soya wax candles in re-purposed containers, including vintage cups and saucers, as well as honey pots adorned with bees.She said: ldquoI also make wax melts and vegan cruelty-free soap. I have been making vintage style Christmas cards and tags too. The main aim is to make products that are environmentally friendly.One recent customer was a hotel in East Lothian, where bosses felt her vintage teacup and saucer candles fitted in well with the high teas offered in its restaurant.Evie is planning to study for a health-related degree at university next year.She said: ldquoI am hoping to continue with my business throughout my studies.ldquoI am very lucky to have parents that support me in whatever I choose to do.For more information, go to facebook bonniemelts

title: emma-salisbury-releases-second-ds-kevin-coupland-book-2020
story: Emma Salisbury set herself the challenge of writing two more books in her DS Kevin Coupland series this year, rather than her usual one.Sticks and Stones was published in April and she has now released the seventh book in the series, When Darkness Falls.In the novel, set in Salford, where Emma was born, the body of a teenage girl is found two days after she is reported missing.A discussion with the pathologist reveals that another girl was found in similar circumstances.DS Coupland looks into the earlier case and finds that outdated views and social stereotyping have thwarted the investigation from the beginning.Alongside acting DS Chris Ashcroft, he lts the lid on a world where victims are defined by their postcode, and where certain crimes are written off as lestyle choices.However, beneath a layer of public indference lies a world far darker than Coupland thought possible and, just when he thinks he is getting closer to the perpetrators, a child goes missing and blows everything he thought he had discovered out of the water.And on top of all this, a couple of characters from previous novels have been brought back.Emma told the Courier she had always wonderedshe would be able to produce double her usual workload.She admitted that during lockdown she struggled to ldquomake sense of what was going on, having been forced to stay away from her family and friends, and writing her new book was a form of therapy.Emma had debated whether to mention coronavirus and lockdown in her latest story but, as she wanted her book to be as realistic as possible, she opted to refer to the situation of recent months.She said: ldquoHopefully readers like the book ndash itrsquos what they want and the feedback will be that itrsquos challenged their perspective on some things.ldquoBashing away with the book certainly helped me make sense of all that is going on right now.ldquoItrsquos been a very productive year but now Irsquom going to enjoy Christmas with my family.Askedthis would be the last book in her Coupland series, Emma said that fans would never forgive hershe were to end it now!Coupland has gained many fans over the years, with electronic versions of the series being downloaded more than , times and Emma receiving messages from readers every day.Next year, Emma plans to start work on a screenplay, believing there is demand for a Coupland TV show.She added that some fans imagined actor Tom Hardy as her famous detective.When Darkness Falls is available on Amazon.

title: bonnie-prince-charlie-horseback-statue-hopes-blindwells
story: The Battle of Prestonpans Trust is looking into creating the first equestrian statue of the Jacobite hero in his home country, overlooking the site of his most famous victory.The trust has been in talks with developers who are building the new town of Blindwells in East Lothian, which lies east of Prestonpans and on part of the site of the famous battle of .And as detailed plans for the new town layout were unveiled , the trust revealed it hoped to have a centre dedicated to the famous battle open in the town by .Plans to secure funding for the centre, which is expected to be in the town, begin next year and the trust has revealed it hopes to sponsor the equestrian statue as part of its efforts.A spokesperson for the trust said: ldquoThe centre has the potential with the support already promised from VisitScotland to bring many thousands of visitors to the economic benefit of the new community and to provide an important destination for myriad school groups.ldquoIt will also ensure signicant sharing of the extraordinary cultural legacy of the princersquos victory in both English and Gaelic.ldquo[Applicants] Hargreavesrsquo plans and the potential they can deliver for our community and our heritage have the trustrsquos deliberate support. They demonstrate precisely the wisdom necessary to conserve and interpret the nationrsquos heritage that is required as society addresses its evolving needs.ldquoWe are, for the record, also ambitious to sponsor Scotlandrsquos first equestrian statue of Bonnie Prince Charlie.Currently the only equestrian statue of Bonnie Prince Charlie is situated at Cathedral Green, Derby, which was the furthest point south the prince reached in his bid to restore a Stuart to the throne.The Blindwells project saw public consultations held online this month after detailed plans for the layout of the new town were released.Hargreaves set out a proposal for , houses, along with a town centre which will be created around a body of water named The Princersquos Loch in the north of the site.Following the public consultation, detailed planning applications are expected to be submitted to the council.

title: winton-estate-features-new-book-celebrating-trees
story: Author Vicky Allan and photographer Anna Deacon, whose book For The Love Of Trees gathered stories told by tree lovers, joined Sir Francis Ogilvy, who runs the Winton Estate, on a walk through the groundsrsquo woodlands, near Pencaitland.Sir Francis said: ldquoI was asked about the relevance of trees to a family estate where tree-planting and woodland management span centuries.ldquoAs a land agent and amateur forester, I relate easily with the passion for trees that jumps out from the [bookrsquos] pages.ldquoNow that I can see the whole book and the extraordinary collection of contributions ndash particularly since they were gathered during the Covid lockdown ndash I am filled with a desire for a wider debate of the contribution from trees and how we go forward from here.The book was produced by Vicky and Anna, who both live in Edinburgh, during lockdown and reflects the connection with nature that was nurtured by many people during this time.A spokesperson from its publisher, Black  White Publishing, said: ldquoAt a time when humanityrsquos relationship with nature is under serious examination and renewed reflection and when the worldwide carbon footprint spirals dangerously upward, trees are an increasingly important and essential part of our survival on Planet Earth.Sir Francis said: ldquoWe are witnessing extraordinary times. The facts about our environment and the effects, both positive and negative, surrounding trees around the world are well documented.ldquoHuge emphasis is placed now on tree planting, assuming that it can be done at the wave of a politicianrsquos wand.ldquoWhen planted, a tree may be the size of a ruler ndash much smaller and arguably more tender than a baby.ldquoThe trees that provide the grandeur and benefits to both the environment and to our wellbeing all take care and continuous investment throughout the le of the tree.ldquoThe economics of growing trees is a vital element to any follow-on discussion for how we develop an articulated lsquolove of treesrsquo into a sustainable programme.Sir Francis, who owns Haddington-based chartered surveyors, estate agents and architects Ogilvy Chalmers, added: ldquoIn  years of being involved in estate forestry in Scotland and England, I have yet to find an example of it being done profitably ndash notwithstanding public perception. For erse woodlands ndash typically found on country estates ndash their management is an annual expense.ldquoMy forestry lecturer extolled the merits of multi-purpose forestry: species ersity timber quality landscape shelter for farming and habitat for wildle.ldquoWe desperately need a holistic understanding of the benefits of trees and how to provide these as economically and widespread as possible.ldquoThere is plenty of room for long-term thinking and policy-making that shows we have listened to those who articulate so well the merits of trees.ldquoThat way, perhaps, future generations can say we listened and we acted ndash maybe late, but still in time.

title: two-new-helms-dunbar-rnlis-inshore-lifeboat-welcomed

scheme and stayed ever since.ldquoThere have been a few shouts in that time but one that always sticks out was when we were tasked to tow a -foot sperm whale off the beach at Canty Bay.ldquoI was attaching the rope when I slipped and fell onto it ndash not an experience you forget in a hurry!Currently a driving instructor in a career that has seen him serve with the police for  years and work Dunbar community.Chris has made a big impact since joining, becoming a mechanic on the all-weather leboat , tractor driver for the ILB and a recipient of the Crewmember of the Year award three people on board and we had to get them all off safely as quickly as we could but many of them thought we were joking!Chris and Ross paid thanks to the existing helms and crew for their help in title: last-minute-christmas-ideas-craft-gifts-decorations
story: But with no major changes likely to the public health advice for the foreseeable future, why not put the extra time spent at home to good use Therersquos a plethora of crafts that you can take up over the next few daysndash creating your own festive decorations or even a truly meaningful Christmas gt for someone.You will be learning a new skill, while best of all, saving money, so herersquos some of our favourite festive crafts.. Breathe new le into old wine bottlesLetrsquos face it, we all have a lot of wine bottles lying around over Christmas. But with some councils requiring you to venture to a bottle bank to recycle them, it can be a bit of an inconvenience to have them lying around the house and taking up space.The good news is that therersquos lots of craft that you can employ to make these old bottles into a kitschy decoration. One of the most popular is to buy some tall candles, shave them around the base so they are thin enough to fit into the opening of the bottle, then simply let the candle burn down so that the wax drips down in a rustic fashion.Alternatively, you can use old fabric to stitch together a Santa hatto sit over the bottle as a festive centrepiece. And, of course, you donrsquot have to use wine bottles ndash any bottle will do.. Make decoupage Christmas cardsRequiring much more effort than just picking up a multipack of Christmas cards, decoupage is a great way to show that you care.There are plenty of designs that you can get online , but you will need a steady hand and lots of patience to cut out and stack each inidual layer.Itrsquos a great task to do with older kids, getting them to use their hand-eye coordination on something other than a games console, with a real sense of accomplishment when you see the finished version.Just make sure to leave enough time to send them out before the final Christmas posting dates .Christmas is just around the corner. Go foraging for rustic decorationsOne of the best things to come out of lockdown is that most of us have gained a renewed sense of appreciation for the outdoors.With rustic decorations firmly back in fashion, why not use your next woodland walk as an opportunity to pick up some greenery to add to your home  Holly and ivy can be found across the country, particularly in oak and beech woodland, with holly branches traditionally used to decorate homes while serving as a charm against witches.You can also thread greenery through bannisters, or to dress your table for Christmas day, with eucalyptus and mistletoeadding a delicate touch. Herbs like rosemary look great on top of Christmas cakes, while pinecones can be fun for kids to find and then paint before displaying in a jar or a basket.. Create a mini Christmas tree from plastic spoonsIt might sound tacky, but a mini tree made from plastic spoons can look surprisingly classyyou do it right.Simply pick up a multipack of disposable plastic spoonsand then cut off the circular spoon heads and discard the handles.From there, paint or decorate the spoon circles before gluing them in layers to a kitchen roll or similar base to create a fanned Christmas tree shape. You can even make a spoon trees of dferent sizes and display them together for a charming decoration.Find out more here.. Decoratefestive candleCandle sales have soared in the UK in the last few months, as we seek to make the dark nights spent at home feel warmer, cosier and more lsquohyggersquo. And as demand rises so does the prices, with some branded scented candles costing hundreds of pounds.But therersquos no need to spend a fortune. Instead, you can pick up some plain inexpensive candles and then decorate them yourself- getting all of the visual impact for a fraction of the price.The options are pretty much endless when it comes to decoration: you can paint the candle, add glue then sprinkle it with glitter, tie ribbons or seasonal herbs around the outside, stick on jewels or embellishments, use a template to trace on a designhellip we could go on.You can also make the candle itself from scratch and add your own scents, but you will need to buy wax, wicks and fragrance oils to do so.. Distil your own Christmas ginThe craft gin boom of recent years has seen no shortage of gins vying for your attention in the alcohol aisle. Butyou want to really impress this Christmas, why not distil your own Therersquos plenty of sets containing dried botanicals that you can buy online, or acquire independently, with some of the most popular being orange peel, peppercorn, cardamom, cinnamon, liquorice or rose petals.You can add whatever combinations of botanicals you like but, to qualy as a gin, juniper must be the most dominant botanical and the spirit must be at least .% ABV.All you really need to do is get a glass bottle or jar, add your chosen combination of botanicals and then top with quality vodka. Leave your infusion in a dark cupboard for around a week, shaking it once a day, then sieve out the botanicals to leave you with your gin.Experiment with some festive flavours for an extra bit of pizzazz.. Create some frosty branchesThese are incredibly easy and cheap to make despite being sold for signicantly more in most garden centres. Gather some branches or twigs from outside, prune them into the shape that you want and then spray paint them gold or silver. Then fill a plastic tub with glitter, add glue to your branches and dip them in the glitter before leaving to dry. Itrsquos best to do this all outside to minimise mess- so make sure the weather is dry while you do so. Once your frosty branches are complete you can either display them outside or in a vase indoors- they look particularly good when illuminated by a candle or the twinkle of Christmas lights.Get the tutorial here.. Make peppermint candy canesLegend has it that candy canes were invented by a Cologne choirmaster in the th century who wanted to remind children of the role of shepherds in the story of the nativity.From there they spread throughout Europe, now becoming one of the most popular decorations for our homes at Christmas. The good news is that they are reasonably easy to bake, meaning the whole family can get involved, while also requiring very few ingredients.Simply mix peppermint extract with dferent colours of pre-bought icingand then make two long sausages containing each colour.Twist the sausages together, slice into smaller pieces, mould into the desired hook shape and then leave them to set on a baking tray for  hours. Then, either eat your candy canes or use them as decorations.Get recipe inspiration here.Make your own fake snow!. Make fake snowDespite listening to songs about it every year, a white Christmas is actually pretty rare, with the last widespread one in Britain coming back in .But with no snow guaranteed outside, you can still create your own with just a handful of ingredients that you are likely to have lying around the house.Kids will love joining in and mixing the snow through their hands- so be sure to get them involved. Simply mix together equal measures of cornflour and bicarbonate of soda in a bowl, slowly adding water while mixing it together with your hands.Yoursquoll know yoursquove got the right consistency when the lsquosnowrsquo can hold its own shape while still being easily remodelled. Alternatively, you can mix the cornflour with hair conditioner or shaving cream for a similar effect.. Make your own e-cardPersonalised cards are currently all the rage. But rather than shelling out for cards on personalisation websites, you can photoshop photos of your loved ones onto a range of festive backgrounds that are available online for free.Most of these templates require only basic skills to use and once yoursquove made them, you can either print them out or send in an email to avoid wasting paper- keeping your Christmas carbon footprint down.Try here.

title: coronavirus-strict-new-christmas-rules-level-4-coming-east-lothian
story: In an announcement on Saturdayevening, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon stated that the plans to relax rules for five days over the Christmas period could no longer take place in any part of Scotland due to the emergence of a new strain of Covid- which can spread up to  per cent more easily than previous strains.The key points set out by the First Minister are:In her statement, the First Minister described the situation as the most serious juncture since the start of the pandemic.She said: "If we dont act firmly and decisively now, [the new strain of the virus] will take hold here."By January, our NHS could potentially be overwhelmed... it would mean many more people dying from this virus than would otherwise have been the case."Its important that we take the warning we are being given now very seriously."If we do act now, we have a chance of keeping the situation under control."She stated that she understood that, due to the fact Scotlands case numbers were currently not as high as those in England and Wales, many people would question why the strict new rules were being brought in, but she said it was critical to act now to stop the situation rapidly spiralling out of control.On the travel ban from other parts of the UK, she stated: "That ban will remain in place right throughout the festive period."We simply cannot allow the risk of this strain travelling from other parts of the UK."Although she said that indoor mixing in a bubble would still be allowed on Christmas Day, she urged people to avoid even thatpossible, stating: "Our advice is still not to meet indoors, even on Christmas Day,you can possibly avoid it."On Christmas Day, she said the law was that no more than eight people from no more than three households would be allowed to meet indoors.She also said that, although travel between dferent parts of Scotland would be allowed on Christmas Day, staying overnight would not be, telling those who would need to do so not to travel at all.And she added that immediately after the end of Christmas Day, the strictest Level  measures would apply for all mainland Scotland for a minimum of three weeks. The first review of the levels will take place after two weeks.Level , the highest ofScotlands five levels, stops households mixing, shuts pubs and restaurants and closes non-essential retail. For more information on what is and isnt allowed in Level , see here.As for schools, she said that most pupilsafter the Christmas holidays would be delayed by a week.Pupils in East Lothian had been due toto school on January  but now this will be the case only for the children of key workers and for the most vulnerable.For the majority of pupils, the holidays will be extended until January  and learning will take place online until at least January , after which it is hoped schools will be able to reopen fully.And the First Minister added: "Standing here saying this actually makes me want to cry because I know how harsh this sounds, I know how unfair it is."But this virus is unfair it doesnt care about Christmas, it only cares about spreading itself as far and wide as possible and it has just got better at that."

title: royal-mail-last-posting-dates-christmas-2020-delays-possible
story: A double-hit of more online shopping and tight restrictions caused by the coronavirus pandemic have now been made even worse by the vast reduction in Christmas lsquobubblersquo rules over the weekend - meaning more people may take to posting presents rather than giving in person.The postal service previously said it was experiencing an "exceptionally high volume of post" but is working hard to get post delivered as fast as possible.The last postal dates for Christmas this year are:Earlier in the month, a statement from Royal Mail said: "We are working hard to deliver the most comprehensive and high-quality service we can to all our customers, large and small."The combination of greatly increased uptake of online Christmas shopping, in no small part driven by the recent lockdown, and the ongoing Covid- restrictions mean that all delivery companies are experiencing exceptionally high volumes this year.Wersquore working hard to deliver the most comprehensive and high quality service we can to all our customers. title: elphinstone-primary-school-pinkie-st-peters-nursery-closed
story: A shortage of staff as a result of the positive Covid- cases at Elphinstone Primary and at the nursery at Pinkie St Peters have resulted in their closure ndash although the school at Pinkie St Peters remains open, while pupils at Elphinstone Primary will learn remotely for the final two days of term.A message sent to parents and carers at Elphinstone Primary yesterdaysaid: "Someone from Elphinstone Primary School has tested positive for Covid-. This has resulted in a number of people who had been in close and sustained contact with this inidual being asked to self-isolate as a precaution."Unfortunately, we will not have enough teaching staff in school for the remaining two days of term and there are no available supply teachers who are able to come to the school."As a result, we have taken the very dficult decision that all pupils will need to move to remote learning for the final two days of term ndash Monday and Tuesday."This means that your child will not be able to attend school in person on Monday and Tuesday and will need to work from home instead."We appreciate that this decision will be frustrating and inconvenient and we are having to move quickly on completion of the contact tracing process following this recent confirmed case. However, under these very dficult circumstances, we believe this decision is the only option open to us and is in the interests of everyonersquos health and safety."We had developed remote blended as a contingency ahead of the re-opening of our schools in August and will now be calling upon these arrangements. This of course follows our experience of delivering remote learning during the spring summer term."We want to reassure parents that appropriate tasks and assignments will be readily available for pupils on Monday and Tuesday via Google Classroom."Since the start of this pandemic, our school community has taken every precaution possible to limit the transmission of Covid-. We are all hugely proud of the work of all staff , children and the support of parents under extremely dficult and unprecedented circumstances. This has enabled us to maintain high-quality learning and teaching since the reopening of the school in August."However, this situation highlights that Covid- continues to present a signicant risk. It is important that everyone around the country continues to follow the really important national public health advice, including the importance of observing lsquoFACTSrsquo ndash including wearing face coverings where recommended, avoiding crowded areas, cleaning hands, two-metres physical distancing and self-isolatingsymptoms develop."Meanwhile, an East Lothian Council spokesperson said of the case at Pinkie St Peters nursery: "We were notied of someone from Pinkie St Peters Primary School Nursery who has tested positive for Covid-."A number of people who had been in close and sustained contact with this inidual are being asked to self-isolate as a precaution."Unfortunately, there are not enough teaching staff in the nursery for the remaining two days of term and there are no available supply teachers who are able to come to the nursery."Consequently we are having to close the Nursery on Monday and Tuesday."However, parents and carers at all other schools in East Lothian have received the following message: "Following public health advice, the Scottish Government advises schools should remain OPEN until the end of term."Public health has also confirmed our schools and early learning and childcare settings have, and should continue with, the effective measures already in place."We understand that some parents have been in touch to say they will keep their child at home. If you intend to keep your child at home, please inform your school as you normally would."On Tuesday, we will update parents and carers about arrangements for the start of the new term in January ."First Minister Nicola Sturgeon previously announced on Saturday that only the children of keyworkers and the most vulnerable wouldto school as originally planned on January , with school not starting for all other pupils until January  and remote learning taking place until at least January .

title: plans-revealed-phased-return-east-lothian-pupils-school-january
story: The delay, put in place to suppress the spread of Covid-, will be introduced to take account of public health advice.Schools in East Lothian had initially been due toon January , but in an January .But schools that had planned to be open this week in the run-up to Christmas will remain so.Mr Swinney said: ldquoThese exceptional phased reopening arrangements are being put in place in light of the latest developments in the path of the virus.ldquoThey are designed to allow an assessment of community transmission after the festive period.ldquoSchools that planned to open this week should follow their existing end-of-term arrangements.ldquoThis decision has been taken because we judge that current levels of prevalence in Scotland remain safe for schools to open.ldquoAfter that, assuming we are confident we have the virus under control, we aim to reopen schools more fully.ldquoUntil then, schools will go online only except for the children of key workers and the most vulnerable.In East Lothian, teachers willto schools on January , while children of key workers and the most vulnerable children willon January .For the majority of pupils, therefore, the holiday period will effectively be extended until January  schools will remain closed to them but online learning will take place from January  to .From Monday, January , schools will be open to all staff and pupils for in-person teaching as normal.All these measures will be kept under regular review.All children who are eligible for free school meals will continue to receive them during this period.Lesley Brown, East Lothian Council executive director of education and childrens services, said: "These are exceptional arrangements being put in place as a precautionary measure."Whilst we appreciate this fully committed to ensuring our schools are as safe as possible and that we maintain the highest possible quality of learning and teaching for all."

title: thousand-christmas-boxes-delivered-families-elderly-residents-around-musselburgh
story: One thousand Christmas boxes containing gts such as clothes, gloves, socks and chocolates meal packs for  families and wellbeing hampers for about  elderly residents were distributed by Musselburgh Area Partnership which is hoping to continue to make ldquoa positive dference in the community amidst the Covid- pandemic.More than  activity packs containing Christmas crafts, a baking idea, DIY hot chocolate and marshmallows, and word searches, as well as clothes and toys were given to local children.The town also looks set to receive a large proportion of , meals from independent hospitality provider BaxterStorey in a New Year initiative which Councillor Andy Forrest, a Musselburgh ward member, helped organise. title: zans-wildlife-diary-arrival-waxwings-east-lothian-winter
story: When I was younger, I could spend hours standing at the window watching the snow fall. I was always mesmerised by how quickly the rough landscape changed into a white wonderland like from the most beautul fairy tale. This was also the time that I associated with countless presents . Who does not like them !Now I still adore winter but for dferent reasons, namely for its wildle visitors to the country. Last month, I introduced you to one of them ndash the short-eared owl ndash and now it is time I presented my favourite winter migrant: the Bohemian waxwing.The sight of a waxwing can brighten up any winter day, regardless of how keen on birding you are. Two years ago, I was privileged to spend a fantastic afternoon with these birds.It was a chilling but sunny day. As my dad, who is a nature lover, was visiting me for Christmas, I took the opportunity to take him on a trip to Aberlady. This place is always rich in all sorts of wildle. I also knew that some waxwing sightings had been recorded earlier that week.As soon as we arrived, I spotted a rather big flock of birds that briefly circulated above our heads before disappearing towards the reserve. Everything happened so fast that I did not have enough time to pick up my binoculars for a closer look at the birds.We rushed towards a copse of rowan trees, where I knew the waxwings would most likely congregate. As we were coming closer, I could recognise the merry trill that these stunning birds make as they were happily feeding on berries. You may remember from my previous articles how careful I am when it comes to approaching wildle. This time was no dferent we took our time watching the waxwings from a distance, letting them get used to our presence. This is a great technique to signal to wildle that we are no threat to them.Suddenly, the flock was spooked by a dog and raised high in the sky for a split second before landing above our heads. My dad and I gave each other a knowing grin and started admiring the beautul creatures sitting merely a couple of metres away from us. This was an unusual moment to me as a wildle photographer: the birds were so close that my lens was too big to capture the scene! But that picture of waxwings having a feast right above me will stay in my memory for a long time.Waxwings are often mistaken for common starlings. These two species are similar in size and, to an extent, profile.However,you look closely, you should spot the peach-brown colouring of waxwingsrsquo plumage. An even closer look will reveal the real charm and beauty that these birds possess: the enlivening neutral base colours are accompanied by splashes of white and red in the wings and a strong yellow band at the base of the tail. The head is crowned by a distinctive crest, which can be raised or lowered depending on the birdrsquos mood. Adding to their appeal is the prominent black mask on their eyes.Waxwings are gregarious birds, who can form large flocks consisting of hundreds of iniduals. They breed in boreal forest that extends from Scandinavia through Russia and across to the Pacic coast.Waxwings are a forgiving subject to photograph they do not encounter humans within their breeding habitats, therefore are approachable on their winter grounds, providing a great opportunity to capture them feeding on colourful berry trees.Waxwings make a loud but cheerful trill as they scour the landscape looking for fruit.Berries are incredibly important for waxwings in the winter. These birds can eat up to twice their body weight, which makes around -, berries a day!Their diet changes during their breeding season as the birds switch to feeding on mosquitoes and midges.Our native rowan is their favoured tree, but they will happily feed on hawthorn, cotoneaster and rosehips as well as dried fruit.If waxwings are in the area and you do not have berries, they can be attracted into gardens using apple halves hung from a tree. It is common to spot waxwings in such ordinary places as supermarket car parks, as they often have ornamental shrubs with berries.This was my first year writing Zanrsquos Wildle Diary and I have greatly enjoyed sharing my stories and experiences with you. I hope you all had fun reading my column!If you have enjoyed my pictures this year and would like to see more, I now have Wildle Calendars  for sale. Get in touch for more details.I would like to wish you all a very merry Christmas and a happy New Year when it comes!zanslensfacebook zanslens instagram zans_lens twitter zans_lens

title: queen-margaret-university-selected-coronavirus-vaccine-venue
story: NHS Lothian announced the venues yesterday , saying all three were capable of providing thousands of vaccinations at a time.The next phase of the vaccination programme, known as Wave , is shorty expected to begin across Scotland to vaccinate people aged -, followed by those aged - and -, and then adults with risk factors over the age of .NHS Lothian has been working with councils, health and social care partnerships, and other partners to ensure the sites are ready when the roll-out begins, which is expected in February.Edinburgh International Conference Centreand The Pyramids Business Parkin West Lothian have been agreed as two of the centres, and at Queen Margaret University details are being finalised.A number of local supplementary centres are also being set up by the four health and social care partnerships across the Lothian healthboard area to supplement the bigger venues.David Small, director of primary care and transformation at NHS Lothian, who is leading the programme, said he was delighted that three large-scale venues had been agreed.He said: ldquoThis is the biggest mass vaccination programme undertaken. It is a massive task and even though all of the teams are working at speed, we know we need to make sure we get the delivery right, first time.ldquoThere are a lot of challenges involved across the project, but we are meeting each one and we are delighted that these three venues are finalised.ldquoWe still have a number of other options to consider and explore, but this is a milestone.ldquoIt means we can begin work in the new year while we continue planning the smaller centres which will supplement the bigger venues.Sir Paul Grice, principal of Queen Margarey University, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be able to play this part in the national effort to run the biggest mass vaccination programme ever undertaken.ldquoI am very grateful for the efforts of staff across the university to facilitate this, and to East Lothian Council for its support in putting the arrangements in place to allow it to happen.At the Musselburgh-based university, a drive-through vaccination centre is being planned that would have about  stations and be able to vaccinate , people a week.It is expected that a section of the universitys car park will be used for this.Plans are being developed to create a walk-through centre at the EICC which would be capable of vaccinating , a week at about  stations.A similar walk-through centre is expected to be set up in PBP, which could provide , vaccinations every week using about  stations.People will be contacted by the NHS when they are eligible for a vaccination appointment.People should not contact the venues directly as they would not hold any of the relevant information.This new phase will be followed in the spring by the roll-out of Wave , which will also target inidual age groups, starting with those aged -, then -, - and then followed by the rest of the population.

title: tracey-sadek-moores-150km-run-around-streets-east-linton
story: Tracey Sadek-Moore decided to challenge herself during lockdown and after giving birth to her second son, Zayn, earlier this year.The East Linton mum pledged to run a total of  kilometresover  days ahead of Christmas Eve in a bid to raise funds to help people put some Christmas light and warmth into their homes.The HR consultant at Peoplersquos Energy told the Courier that the money would go to the energy providerrsquos community interest fund.She said: ldquoJust having my maternity leave, I wanted to do something for me, to lose a bit of weight and, with lockdown, more for my mindset.ldquoI wanted to challenge myself to do something I did not think I could do.ldquoI have never done running before and I went out and started enjoying the outdoors, walking and running.The -year-old was keen to help people facing fuel poverty, particularly as winter started to bite.She added: ldquoI cannot begin to imagine how it must feel to sit in a cold, dark, silent room with my and I want to help.Originally, Tracey set a fundraising target of pound, with a vow to don her pyjamas and go for a runthat target was achieved.Already it has been passed, with Tracey receiving support from not just the village but as far afield as Dubai and Egypt.Now she has raised pound,.She tries to run between five and eight kilometres daily around the streets of East Linton, with runs something my son is really getting behind, cheering me on.ldquoWhen you get past the aching muscles, it is something for your health and wellbeing but your mindset as well.ldquoI feel great after a run and it really does help.To make a donation, go to www.gofundme f hfypxaw
