title: janey-godley-dolly-parton-professor-devi-sridhar
story: In many ways, they are anonymous. An army of healthcare workers shrouded by layers of protective clothing, masks and visors. They are doctors and nurses and paramedics and care workers, toiling tirelessly theand breadth of Scotland.We may not know their names but back in the spring, all across the country, people stood on doorsteps and applauded at pm on Thursday evenings. We drew rainbows and displayed them on windows, walls, fence railings and lamp posts as a symbol of gratitude.That heartfelt appreciation extends to all key workers: the emergency services, military personnel, delivery drivers, shop employees, teachers, waste collectors, manufacturers, warehouse operatives, postal workers, cleaners, vets, engineers and more.There came shock and anger at the horrendous death toll as coronavirus spread through care homes, the fallout of which will reverberate for years to come. In more recent weeks, there was a glimmer of hope as the first Covid- vaccines were administered to elderly residents and staff.This summer, photographer Elaine Livingstone visited the intensive care unitat Glasgow Royal Infirmary. She captured a series of powerful portraitsof medical staff as they worked on the Covid- frontline.Ruth Whyte, a charge nurse, has worked in intensive care for  years. She told our sister paper, the Glasgow Times, about the many challenges she and her colleagues faced, not least when it came to making that much-needed connection with patients.ldquoWith the PPE and without visitors, things that would come naturally to you, you had to work that bit harder for, she said. ldquoFinding out about them and building a picture of them as a person was a bit like being a detective.ldquoTouch is so important to us, but they didnrsquot have somebody there holding their hand, so to me I felt like I was their nurse and their visitor.When it comes to our heroes of , we are thinking about Ruth and all those like her. Those who selflessly went above and beyond. Those who laid their own lives on the line to help others. Those who brought much-needed light to the darkness of this annus horribilis.Laura Muir and Jemma ReekieIn March, when Scotland went into lockdown, athletes and training partners Laura Muir and Jemma Reekie moved in together to continue their journey towards Tokyo . The Olympics may have been postponed but the duo, coached by Andy Young, have had an incredible year.Muir broke the British record for ,m and set a world lead over ,m. She went sub-four minutes in the ,m on three occasions ndash setting the fastest times in the world this year. The five-times European champion produced a trio of blistering runs, clocking :. in Berlin, :. in Stockholm and :. in Chorzow.A delighted Jemma Reekie is hugged by Laura Muir after breaking the British indoor m record at Emirates Arena in GlasgowReekie has broken the indoor British m, mile and ,m records in . She led the world indoor m rankings with :., also breaking British, Scottish and British under- records along the way. Unbeaten in all but one m race this year, Reekie has run five of the worldrsquos top  times. Thatrsquos fast legs.Don MacPheeWhen a car crashed into the River Clyde, Renfrew ferry skipper Don MacPhee had no hesitation about ing in to save the driverrsquos le.The father-of-five from South Uist was guiding the ferry towards the Yoker slip when the drama unfolded in May. He said: ldquoI could see [the car] was beginning to be dragged downstream and we cracked the boat into gear and nipped over. We edin and got the woman out. Itrsquos just what you do.It was a case of right place, right time: MacPhee had been due to go home to the Outer Hebrides in late March after a training course, but when the UK went into lockdown two days before he was set to leave, he remained in Renfrew. Serendipity.Tao Geoghegan HartSome may say that Scotlandrsquos claim on Tao Geoghegan Hart ndash who won the Giro drsquoItalia in October ndash is tenuous but hear us out. While born in London, he qualies on account of having a Scottish father .There was talk of Geoghegan Hart competing for Team Scotland at Glasgow  , but, at the time, he had newly signed with the Hagens Berman Axeon cycling team and committed to a US-based race programme. Who knows  Maybe in the future.It would be remiss not to mention the success of Scots cyclists Katie Archibald and Neah Evans who won double goldat the European Track Cycling Championships in Bulgaria last month.:Two Doors Down stars Jonathan Watson and Doon Mackichan get festiveTheir stellar victory in the team pursuit on November  may not have got the attention it deserved given the Scotland menrsquos football team qualied for the Euros that same night. Next stop: Tokyo  .Special mention to rising Scottish stars Lusia Steele, who took silver in her elite level debut at the European Track Cycling Championships, and Cameron Mason for his bronze medal ride in the menrsquos under- European Cyclo-cross Championships.Janey GodleyThe easy thing would have been to do nothing. To sit at home, glued to the news and feel the anxiety rise like millions of other Scots. But thatrsquos not the Janey Godley way.Instead, the Glasgow comedian and actor began a series of voiceovers: her take on First Minister Nicola Sturgeonrsquos daily coronavirus briefing. The result was informative and hilarious as Godley imparted key messages in easy-to-understand, bite-sized clips. She went viral for talking about a virus.Memorable moments include a sweary outburst about former chief medical officer Dr Catherine Calderwood ldquobending the rules by visiting her second home in Fe during lockdown and advising listeners that there should be ldquonae rumpy pumpy between couples living in dferent households.Godley ended each video with her catchphrase ldquoFrank, get the door! Ma feet are killing me, usually accompanied by an internal monologue of Sturgeon ruminating about what she would have for lunch .The spoof broadcasts ndash viewed by millions ndash have been praised by the Royal Society of Edinburgh for helping to tackle the spread of the pandemic in Scotland, saying that the skits have been effective in getting the public to take action to prevent the spread of the virus.By adding ldquocomedy and relatability, her sartorial musings are said to have encouraged people to engage with repetitive prevention messages about social distancing, staying at home, washing hands and wearing a mask.Comedian Janey GodleyNor was that all Godley achieved in . With theatres and comedy venues closed, she found other ways to put her time to good use. Alongside her daughter Ashley Storrie, a fellow comedian, Godley has raised more than pound, for charity, including the STV Childrenrsquos Appeal and Carers Trust Scotland.Godley did a quartet of poignant and funny online plays as part of National Theatre of Scotlandrsquos Scenes For Survival called Alone Part I and II .She wrote a bookand has penned a novel due out next year. Godleyrsquos comedy short film, The Last Mermaid, won best actress at the  Scottish Short Film Awards. She was named Scots Speaker of the Year at  Scots Language Awards.Not bad going by any measure. Here, Godley shares a brief summary of her year:Standout moments of  Captain Tomrsquos incredible achievement and watching Nicola Sturgeon say ldquoFrank, get the door! in the comedy sketch we did for the STV Childrenrsquos Appeal.What are you most proud of Being able to stay creative during the anxiety and fear of the coronavirus pandemic.Biggest lesson learned I really donrsquot need to buy that many clothes in a year and I need to recycle my personal stuff as it doesnrsquot mean that much.Hopes for  Recovery for business and peoplersquos mental health.Captain SirTom MooreCometh the hour, cometh the -year-old man. Captain Sir Tom Moorersquos sudden rise to national-treasuredom speaks volumes about the year wersquove battled through and what we looked to as symbols of hope.In a period in which we lost so many elders, a centenarian became a magnet for both fame and donations. In a time when the NHS felt under threat, he channelled a desire out there to support it and each other.Moorersquos journey started on April , when just a few weeks into lockdown, at the age of , he began to walk laps of this garden as a fundraiser for NHS Charities Together.The idea was that he would raise pound, by his th birthday ndash which was at the end of the month.In those  days he became a superstar as well as raising more than pound million. His was a message of optimism. ldquoFor all those finding it dficult, he said, ldquothe sun will shine on you again and the clouds will go away.:Forensic pathologist Dr Marie Cassidy on her le at the frontline of deathMoore was a man who remembered the Blitz and somehow embodied that spirit of stoicism, community and solidarity.The disease may have shone a light on the inequality in our country, but Moore touched on something we all felt for a moment ndash that we were in it together, and we could help each other.The money, of course, didnrsquot stop flooding in, and the fame didnrsquot stop growing. Over the year he became the first centenarian to have a number one chart hit with his cover version of Yoursquoll Never Walk Alone, published his autobiography, Yoursquoll Never Walk Alone and was knighted by the queen ndash though really, to most of us, he was just Captain Tom.By the time the campaign closed, it had topped pound,,. ldquoIrsquom absolutely overawed, he said in ainterview earlier this month. ldquoNever in  years did I anticipate this would happen to me ndash that my name would go around the world.Andrew CotterSports broadcaster Andrew Cotterrsquos wry commentary about his dogs Olive and Mabel was a much-needed tonic during lockdown. The clips went viral, winning fans around the globe.Cotter, who comes from Troon, Ayrshire and is a regular on the BBC, has written a heart-warming memoir, Olive, Mabel and Me, about their adventures.Len PennieIt is nigh-on impossible not to feel a surge of patriotism at Len Penniersquos Scots Word of the Day. Fe-based Pennie ndash better known to her k Twitter followers as Miss Punny Pennie and @lenniesaurus ndash is a passionate ambassador for the preservation of Scots language.The self-described ldquowarrior poet held together wae spite and duct tape penned and performed Irsquom No Havinrsquo Children, a love letter to ldquoa proud ancient language and one dedicated to the strength of her own mother. Well worth a listen.Dr Kenneth BaillieWhere would we be without the research  It is at the heart of our battle against the virus ndash and the intensive care specialist, Dr Kenneth Baillie, and the lab he leads at the Roslin Institute, has done groundbreaking work.He led, for instance, the recently published, ground-breaking GenOMICC study, which showed genetic associations with critical Covid and that those with particular genes were more likely to get it badly.He also co-led an earlier study which found risk factors for the disease such as obesity and diabetes, and created a prognostic score ndash and he contributed to the set-up and delivery of the RECOVERY trial, which found the first effective treatment, dexamethasone.ldquoI think, he told The Herald last week, ldquomy most striking memory of this year will be all of the willingness of everyone to step forward and help wherever needed. Irsquom thinking of clinical and research staff in hospitals across the whole country, and study managers and lab staff and volunteers.:Angels with dirty faces: The wild swimmers cleaning up our waters"People worked day and night to care for patients in the ICUs, to organise and coordinate research and clinical trials across the whole country, and then to complete complex data analyses inrecord time.Looking to the year ahead, he said, ldquoWe all still have a lot of work left to do and wersquore still seeing people die of Covid in ICUs across the country.ldquoBut it is astonishing that we already have an effective treatmentand an understanding of the genetic mechanisms of the disease that points us towards several more potential treatments.ldquoHopefully we can do the same for other diseases like sepsis and flu, after Covid is controlled.Professor Devi SridharIf one expert voice on Covid and public health has stood out in the last year, itrsquos that of -year-old professor Devi Sridhar, the American scientist who holds the chair in public health at the University of Edinburgh. Sridhar became a kind of public health superstar, speaking out against the ldquoherd immunity approach.In March, she was one of a group of professors who signed a letter to the Lancet criticising the UKrsquos approach to the pandemic, and requesting ldquothat the government urgently and openly shares the scientic evidence, data, and models it is using.She is a member of a group that advises the UKrsquos SAGE team, and one of the experts who advises the Scottish Government.Devi Sridhar, author and professor at the University of Edinburgh. Picture: Roberto Ricciuti Getty ImagesSometimes she came under fire for how outspoken she was ndash for instance, when she issued the tweet, ldquoIt is the tragedy of history that when a serious pandemic hit the world where leadership and good governance were required, Donald Trump was US President and Boris Johnson was UK Prime Minister.Meanwhile, she praised the approach of many of the East Asian countries, which she said, had got it right.What has been clear is that she views the battle against the virus through the prism of equality. Public health, for her, is about all of us ndash and especially the poor, who are set to be hit worst by the virus.Joe WicksThe man who got everyone, and not just the schoolkids, jumping around their living rooms like a kangaroo and doing Spider-Man lunges. Le during lockdown was marked by a number of shared activities ndash and one of them was PE With Joe.Few, certainly, are the families with school-age children who didnrsquot do at least a few Pikachu squats with him. In the months from March to July, when the workouts stopped, he did  PE workouts and had million views, making pound, for the NHS.The nation was working out together ndash though some of us were perhaps not always joining him for the am livestream. They were also being tested for general knowledge, witnessing some daft fancy dress costumes, and following the family journey as Wicks has surgery on his arm and his we, Rosie, stepped in to demonstrate.Joe said in an interview, ldquoPeople now realise they can have a great workout in their living room, or their bedroom or their garden with no equipment, and thatrsquos really what Irsquove been trying to achieve, to make fitness accessible and sustainable for everybody and I really hope that people realise that you donrsquot need an expensive gym membership and loads of equipment to stay fit and healthy ndash thatrsquos really my goal.Monica LennonNowhere  in the world had done it. But, here in Scotland, politicians have not only extensively debated and discussed the Long-taboo subject of periods in our parliament, but passed a bill to provide free and universal access to period products.Monica Lennon, the MSP, who spearheaded a campaign was recently named one of Voguersquos top female leaders who have changed the world. And rightly so. The policy was a first in the world.But also, this four-year campaign got us talking about both poverty and the taboos and stigma around menstruation ndash and at a time when, as a result of the pandemic, poverty is onthe rise.Scottish Labours Monica Lennon. Picture: Gordon Terris The HeraldIt revolutionised the way we talk about periods. As Lennon put it, ldquoA few years ago there had never been an open discussion of menstruation in the Holyrood chamber and now it is mainstream."MSPs have enjoyed being a part of that, and it has encompassed the menopause, endometriosis, as well as the types of products we use and their sustainability.Lennon has even suggested that this law could be replicated throughout the world.Professor Sir Geoff PalmerThis year brought not just a pandemic, but a wave of energy for change around racism, and, in the midst of restrictions, Black Lives Matter protests.In the midst of all this, a powerful voice has been that of Professor Sir Geoff Palmer, Jamaican-born and the first black professor in Scotland. His message was, ldquoDonrsquot take down statues ndash take down racism.The statues, he believes, are part of black history. Rather than remove the statue to Henry Dundas, known as the Melville Monument, he suggested ndash and in fact had already been campaigning some years for ndash a plaque to be added describing how Dundas had played a pivotal role in delaying the abolition of slavery by having the word ldquogradual inserted in William Wilberforcersquos motion.Professor Sir Geoff Palmer. Picture: Martin ShieldsAt the Black Lives Matter protest in Holyrood Park, Palmer made one of the key speeches. In an interview with the BBC this summer, he said, ldquoI donrsquot want statues to be taken down. My view is you remove the evidence, you remove the deed. The past has consequences and a lot of people forget that."Racism is a consequence of the past. You may take street names away but we have dficulty convincing people about the past. Removing it is very tricky because we are altering history.Margaret PayneCaptain Tom might have done laps of his garden, but Margaret Payne of Ard, aimed for giddier heights and climbed the iconic Scottish mountain, Suilven ndash or at least she climbed its  metre height in ascents of the stairs in her Sutherland home.She had been climbing those steps, for exercise before she heard of Tom Moorersquos laps, and it was her daughter who suggested she do something with it, in terms of fundraising for the NHS. ldquoI said, she recalls, ldquowell why canrsquot I climb Suilven  And thatrsquos how it all started.Payne, who spoke to us just after her st birthday this month, said, ldquoI donrsquot feel I deserve all that Irsquove had in terms of attention, because I feel itrsquos really the people who did the publicity and the people who donated who really deserve the thanks.:Diane Lane on her new film Let Him Go and four decades as an actorldquoI did do the stair-climbing but I feel that was a very small part. My daughter spent hours and hours on the telephone organising things.She chose Suilven because it was a mountain she had climbed in her teens, and, in fact, the only mountain that she had ever climbed ldquoto the very top. ldquoYou see Irsquove had a dicky knee all my le, from the time I was about  and so I never did a lot of hill climbing, though Irsquove done quite a lot of walking.The stair-climbing, however, didnrsquot cause that knee a lot of trouble, though it did make it ache sometimes and she had a couple of days off at one point to allow it to recover.ldquoI thoughtI got pound, I would be doing well, she recalls. ldquoBut the final figure is pound,..Scott McPartlinDigital and phone connectivity has never been more of a leline than it has over the last year, and someone who helped keep that going for many was Scott McPartlin, the customer service engineer who was dubbed ldquoOpenreachrsquos Bear Grylls after he camped out on Coll for three days to restore services to a vulnerable resident there who was shielding.McPartlin was one of those people who went above and beyond the call of duty during lockdown. Since there was no accommodation available, due to restrictions, he pitched a tent.On another occasion, he hiked three miles over a Hebridean beach, carrying his tools during a heatwave. McPartlin wasnrsquot alone in going the extra mile, but he embodied for many the urge that was felt across this country.Marcus RashfordOn January  in an FA Cup third round replay between Manchester United and Wolves, the United striker Marcus Rashford came on as a substitute in the second half. Some  minutes later he went off again after a clash with Matt Doherty.Rashford had suffered a double stress fracture in his back and was going to be out for a while. He was still rehabilitating when football shut down in March during the lockdown.Faced with an extended break from the game, rather than mess around playing Football Manager, the -year-old decided to throw himself into a project close to his heart.In March, he teamed up with the charity FairShare to call for donations for children who would not be receiving free meals because schools were closed.ldquoNo child should have to worry where their next meal is coming from, hepointed out.A Manchester lad, Rashford was one of a family of five raised by their single mum. Money was always a problem. He would hear his mother Melanie cry herself to sleep at nights. In short, he grew up knowing what poverty was.Manchester Uniteds Marcus Rashford. Picture: Nick Potts PA WireNow, in a position of security and influence, he has become the countryrsquos most effective poverty campaigner. In the months that followed his injury, as well as giving his own money to the cause, he spoke out in favour of extending free school meals through school holidays in England over the summer.At first the Westminster government rejected his call before being forced into a U-turn. And when MPs in October voted against extending free school meals through the Christmas holidays, Rashford vowed to continue the fight. ldquoThis is not going away any time soon and neither am I.A month later Boris Johnsonrsquos government caved in, agreeing to introduce a coronavirus winter grant scheme and extend the food programme through next yearrsquos holiday periods in England. .Back in April the health secretary Matt Hancock had a go at Premier League footballers, saying they should take a pay cut and play their part during the pandemic. It was a cheap shot .Rashford, measured, committed and knowledgeable has definitely played his part and shown the government up in the process.Steve ClarkeHow long has it been  Some  years. More than two decades since Scotlandrsquos international football team made it to the finals of a major competition. The last time was , when Craig Brown led Scotland to the World Cup in France.After years of mediocrity, Scotlandrsquos play-off victory in Serbia last month was proof that appointing the former Kilmarnock manager Steve Clarke in May last year was a good one. Some of the football the national team has played under him hasnrsquot always been pretty, but it has been effective.: great Scottish festive books, films, TV shows and songsNow the Tartan Army has, coronavirus vaccine permitting, a chance to see the team play England, the Czech Republic and Croatia next summer ndash which raises a new challenge for Clarke.Can he be the first Scottish manager to guide his team past the group stage in a major competition Or is that asking too much  Next year will give us the answer.Douglas StuartIn more than  years, a Scottish author had only won the Booker Prize once before . James Kelman was awarded it in  for his novel How Late It Was, How Late, a victory that caused no little controversy at the time for its use of vernacular language .It may be a measure of how things have changed that this year a novel about a young, gay boy living with his alcoholic mother narrated in a Glaswegian voice barely raised an eyebrow.It may also be a measure of just what an achievement Douglas Stuartrsquos novel Shuggie Bain is, a deeply felt novel about love, addiction and poverty that has an extra kick because it draws on Stuartrsquos own biography. He grew up in Glasgow in the s not knowing his father and living with his alcoholic mum.After she died, he studied textiles in the Borders before working in the fashion industry in New York.But he always nurtured a desire to be a writer and he worked on Shuggie Bain for more than  years. It was worth the wait.In a red-letter year for Scottish fiction, one that gave us new and powerful work from the likes of Ali Smith, Maggie OrsquoFarrell and Kirstin Innes, Stuartrsquos novel was a reminder of how fiction can let us see ndash and more crucially understand ndash other peoplersquos lives no matter how far removed from our own. Or how close.Dolly PartonWriting more than , songs, one or two of them among the best-known songs in the world, would be quite the legacy for most people. But Dolly Partonrsquos gts to the rest of us extends way beyond that.Dolly PartonIn the s she spoke up in support of HIV Aids groups. In , her charity book gting programme for children, Imagination Library, gave away itrsquos  millionth book.And this year, it emerged that while President Trump was busy downplaying the risk of the coronavirus, Dolly was donating m to fund research into the Moderna vaccine.Joe BidenJoe Biden seems a decent enough sort. Getting on a bit, to be fair, maybe a bit too cautious to make a huge dference politically . But his success in Novemberrsquos US Presidential election should be celebrated as much for what he is not as what he is.Closer in the end than many of us would have liked , Bidenrsquos victory in the election represented a rejection of four years of brutal, nasty, grting, stupid and at times racist leadership by possibly the worst man ever to be President. .:Val McDermid on her odd festive traditions and why she loves a Christmas murder mysteryTrump may or may not go away but Trumpism is not likely to disappear any time soon. He was the culmination rather than the initiator of a deeply populist, aggressive coarsening of politics that has been going on for years, aided by social mediaand fuelled by Russian interference.Itrsquos asking a lot of Joe Biden to somehow reset the American body politic, but hopefully in the short term he can at least give us an example of how a President should behave in office. That would bea start.

title: graham-norton-says-goodbye
story: After  years as the mid-morning Saturday DJ, Norton has decided to move on Radio, as it happens. Last Saturday was his last show. ldquoThis is it , Norton announced, one song in, ldquothe end of an error.Anything but. Since Norton took over from Jonathan Ross in the Saturday morning slot, he has been a safe pair of handschatty , mildly waspish, and not too up himself.Indeed, on Saturday, up until the very last link, he consistently steered things away from the maudlin. ldquoBear in mind Irsquom leaving in a taxi, not in a hearse, he reminded listeners.The final show was mostly business as usual. Banter with guests, doing his best to break up a teenage couple during his Grill Graham weekly advice slot and a selection of mild-to-bland music.At the end, Pam Ayres read a poem she had written in his honour and Norton gave his thank yous. ldquoIrsquom getting emotional now. He played out with his favourite song S Club rsquos Reach for the Starsand then he was gone, leaving the keys to Claudia Winkleman.Listen Out For: Whatever Happened to Baby Jane Austen, Radio , Hogmanay, pm. Slightly buried away at a time when everyone is getting ready to say good riddance to a terrible year, this comedy drama stars none other than Dawn French and Jenner Saunders and was written by novelist and screenwriter David Quantick. French and Saunders play feuding celebrity sisters whose spats go up a notch after the publication of a tell-all book.

title: agenda-libraries-provide-comfort-alone-christmas
story: THERE are only days left of  ndash a year we will be glad to leave behind.We have of course some time to wait before we see a normal routine . Currently, many of us are wrestling with how to safely celebrate Christmas. Therersquos a strong belief that Christmas is a time for being with loved ones.However, for many people, Christmas is dficult it can be joyless and a time of extreme loneliness. As many make plans to see family and friends, those who are alone throughout the year experience increased feelings of isolation. Christmas Day, in particular, can be very lonely for some iniduals.Throughout the pandemic, librarians and library staff have been determined to maintain services for communities by pivoting to create new ways of connecting with and engaging members. They have overcome lockdown restrictions and helped stave off loneliness during what has been an incredibly isolating time.The festive period will be no exception to this. Online library services have strengthened and grown signicantly during  and will continue to be available across the country to support people.Despite experiencing a challenging year themselves, with closures and furlough affecting most services, librarians and library staff are putting on special Christmas activities and services. For example, South Ayrshire libraries have created wonderful Christmas displays to support their Connect  Collect service. In addition, theyrsquore distributing a Winter Wanderland craft pack for children and therersquos an associated scavenger hunt for families, which also involves local shops across the local authority area. In Inverclyde, the library service is collecting letters to Santa and running an online Christmas Bedtime Bookbug Session, as well as hosting a special online visit from Santa on the servicersquos Facebook page.Library services play a vital role in tackling social isolation and loneliness all year round. As trusted public spaces, free to use, they truly are accessible to everyone. They are often described as the living rooms of our communities, offering comfort and a space where people come together.This idea is particularly meaningful during the festive period, and more so this festive period after the year wersquove had.The coronavirus pandemic and its associated restrictions ndash lockdown, social distancing, closure of leisure and hospitality venues, event cancellations ndash has created increased feelings of loneliness and isolation among more people. According to the Mental Health Foundation, which conducted a survey during the first national lockdown, one in fourUK adults said they had experienced feelings of loneliness.We have seen recognition of the value of library services strengthening throughout this year. For example, an unintended, but welcome, consequence of the coronavirus lockdown has been a signicant increase in demand for online library services.Their place at the heart of communities means that libraries are highly attuned to the needs of their communities. They know that, for some, libraries offer a leline. Thatrsquos why wersquoll see librarians and library staff do what they can under a "Covid Christmas" to ensure everyone enjoys some comfort and joy.Pamela Tulloch is chief executive at the Scottish Library and Information Council

title: top-100-tunes-scotland-2020-part-4-26-1
story: Live gigswere a no-go, but it allowed bands and artists to take stock and deliver one of the most exciting years for Scottish music that I have seen in the years of this annual best tracks list.This eclectic annual journey began with a long list of over  tracks, distilled to this Top .In this Scots playlist of the most essential tunes of, you will find everything from alternative rock, dance, electronica, hip-hop, rap, indiechoral, punk, post-grunge, folk and... well see for yourself.It is a mix of the known, little known and the unknown, leftfield and mainstream, immediate pop anthems and challenging experimental projects.The -or-so is being published overfour days with the final  revealed on Boxing Day.Next is...the final chapterTop  Tunes from Scotland in  Part  Top  Tunes from Scotland in  Part  #Top  Tunes from Scotland in  Part  #Part - -...The Grand Gestures ft Andrew Howie and Pauline Alexander - Quiet #....Who Cried Wolf  - Used To#A potent and dark first single with a smooth marriage of rap, hip-hop and rock by the exciting Scots duo. It was was created after lead vocalist DeeZy found out that a close relative was terminally ill. Being creative during this time acted as a form of coping mechanism.....Kohla- GorgeousThis brooding RB vs trip hop cracker from the first EP by the Edinburgh singer-songwriter and producer aka Rachel Alice Johnson who cites the likes of Grimes, FKA Twigs and Kate Bush as influence....zildjianpinky - Sprinkler#Irresisible collage of uplting piano-led chillhop from the mysterious Glasgow producer who conspires to make classic-sounding lo-fi and ambient epics.....Kilgour - Whyd I Do That #The Glasgow-based artist band aka Fionn Crossan produces produce a fascinating kaleidoscopic mash of genre-bending instrumentation scattering drum n bass across the kind of dissonnant keyboard and guitar textures favoured by My Bloody Valentine...... Starless ft Steven Lindsay - Somewhere in the NightLike a lost James Bond movie theme song this epic string-strewn nugget, the brainchild of Paul McGeechan, keyboard player of Love  Money, features Steven Lindsay, the front man with the Big Dish, one of the great lost bands of the s.....Taahliah - Mind Body SoulThe first black trans DJ and producer to be nominated and and win in two categories in the Scottish Alternative Music Awards with an unreal, experimental and disorientating dancefloor monster track that shows that this new Glasgow-based artist with nothing officially released is an underground creative force to be reckoned with....Dylan Fraser - I Do These Things For MeThe exciting new-year-old artist from Bathgateis at his best on this darkly twisting electro-synth epic which comes over like a poppier Nine Inch Nails from his superb debut The Storm EP. He says itrsquos about the internet and how you see everyone posting about things they are going to do and achieve but nothing really ever happens.....Still House Plants - CrreeaaseThe Glasgow School Of Art-formed trio are very much a law unto themselves and their latest album, Fast Edit, is a continuation of their harmonic but fractious discordant improvisations which in the wrong hands would just sound like an ambiguous mess. This standout track has its roots in an irresistibly mutated groove, and like a funky abstract of Sonic Youth force fed Red Hot Chili Peppers, hangs together very very nicely while appearing to fall apart at the seams at the same time.....Liam Robertson - Common Weaver...Blue Rose Code ft Karine Polwart -Peace In Your Heart"May this next year go easier on your soul," they croon. Amen to that......Harsh Winters - LiarsA post-rock vs country influenced track from The Marriage of a Killer and a Bird Song, the debut album from the new project by Edinburgh-based singer-songwriter Luke G Joyce who ended up in the home of country music, Nashville for its launch. "My le has changed so much over the last few years ndash for better and for worse ndash and there is a lot of that in this record," he says.....Death Bed - Ice CreamA rabid lo-fi infectious screaming rfola beast made to melt eardrums and make moshpits [should they ever exist again] explode from the Glasgow-based experimental-metallers barnstorming debut album No Breeze In Hell. It could be the angry son of Nirvanas Bleach.....The Wild Places - Fear CityWith an opening guitar hook that has whispers of the Red Hot Chili Peppers Under the Bridge, the Glasgow alt-indie three piece fashion an altogether more atmospheric, mood with a flicker of desolation, a hint of regret and lost love, a smidgeon of optimism, neat loud-soft-loud dynamics, a soaring, spinetingling Thom Yorke vocal pay-off halfway through and a a drum finale that sounds like shots in the dark. An exquisite standout from debut album Wires and easily their most inspired moment to date.....Popup - FollowThis Glasgow four-piece indie-art-pop combo gathered , MySpace fans in a week at a time when that was worth a jot. They released a debut album in  and then nothing...for  years. They then deign to release the devil-may-care second Whimpers with its mash of kitchen-sink Aidan Moffat-style drama and potent guitar jams and this eccentric, messy, fast-slow-fast-faster, thigh-slapping cracker of a third track that sounds like it was made up on the spot. Lazy blighters.....Lewis Capaldi - Before You Go A soaring version of the song about suicide by the superstar Scots singer-songwriter which topped the UK Singles chart in January. He says it was "by far the most personal tune" he had ever written and he drew on feelings surrounding his aunt who took her own le when he was younger......Amy Duncan - The Whole TownThe Hidden World, the seductive seventh album featuring the golden larynx of innovative Edinburgh-born singer-songwriter, who is a classically trained double bass player, is a tantalising and sensual and yet still unsettling not-quite-three-minute melodic meditation underpinned by harp-like synths from another galaxy that just ends far too soon.....LivMassive  Hessian Renegade - TargeThis inspired Glasgow-based experimental collaboration born as a masters degree project, sees the classical folk vibes of viola player LivMassive aka Rachael Olivia Black team up with the rave-rap duo to create a sweeping R Rated pounding blast from their EP Erocean that sounds like nothing  you will ever have heard....Luki - The PartsThe singer, pianist and synth player based in Glasgow says she began her musical career by accident in her late twenties, after making a soundscape for a toilet at a party and realising ndash quite suddenly ndash that everything before had been a mistake. This reveals itself in what in dferent hands could be a standard Tori Amos knock off - but with Lucy Duncans beautully witchy vocals, which sound like their at the edge of an operatic breakdown and an undercurrent of weird sonic noises, you have this barking treasure.The Parts  The Empty Arms by Luki....Glasvegas - Keep Me SpaceSeven years after the release of their last album Laterhellip When The TV Turns To Static, the Glasgows cult heroes with the awful pun band nameed with this triumphant single from their fourth album Godpseed that is a sublime sonic blast of Ramones vs Phil Spector wall of sound vs My Bloody Valentine. With anLP slated for release in April , this tasteris their finest ever four-and-a-bit minutes so far.ldquoI was writing that for my cousin who I grew up with who then, from the age of maybe  or whatever, I never really saw again. In the song I was saying lsquowhatever was then, maybe thatrsquos something thatrsquos foreverrsquo. Because it happened all them years ago maybe you canrsquot touch it, you canrsquot feel a memory, itrsquos not tangible, but thatrsquos not to say that doesnrsquot last forever because thatrsquos maybe floating somewhere. Wherever you are in your thoughts, keep me a spacersquo," says crooner James Allan.....Zoeuml Bestel - Show What Youre Made OfWith one of the purest can sing the telephone directory voices around, the Dumfries and Galloway nu-folk songstress, who has become aregular on this end of year list,put aside her trademark ukelele and recruited collaborators on this compellingly sparse mid-tempo wonky-synth cover of an obscure song by Glasgows Medicine Men. This triumphantly tender tune is the standout track on the Last Night From Glasgow labels The Isolation Sessions album where artists covered each others songs and the proceeds went to venues that had to close due to Covid- lockdown laws.....Conscious Route  True Note - BrothersA skyscraper slice of space-age electro places the Edinburgh-based emcees sharp political posturing onto the dancefloor but with an inspired reflective piano-led twist at the end. In the year where Black Lives Matter has come to the fore, this and Lost Routes, the landmark album it comes from only serves to show that really, the world should never have needed to be told that.....Lizabett Russo - Release....Django Django - Glowing in the DarkThe Edinburgh-formed avant-surf-pop combo are at their very best with this hook-filled acid-inflected breast-banging title track from an eagerly-awaited forthcoming album which is the music equivalent of Pringles - once you pop you cant stop. Built around a sample from one of Dave Macleanrsquos spoken word records then plushly upholstered with Moog synths and drum loops, it is one to play again-and-again-and-again......The Blue Nile - Here Come The BluebirdsA new Blue Nile song. Surely not. But, yes. While unheralded, this is the best of four unreleased songs for a newly remastered and reconstituted version of their fourth album High by one of the greatest ever bands from Scotland. It has all the intimacy and heartbreaking sophistication of their meisterwerk Hats and while ever so slightly stripped down, it has those trademarks building orchestral synths, and provides all the hairs-on-the-back-of-the-neck-standing-on-end moments that their best work always manages. And theres are yeah, yeah, yeahs to boot.If a voice was a Covid vaccine, then Paul Buchanan is the cure......sarya - i dont know where im going This perfectly articulated the feeling of emotional disorientation and heartache that Covid- brought, with the power to wash aside the isolation blues with an irresistible cauldron of indie, electronica and folk sounds and the soaring high-pitched vocal melancholy of the Edinburgh-based Taiwanese-American singer-songwriter poet.It is taken from her glorious third EP Take Care Of Yourself which she describes as a "meditation on self-care, a rap to emotional openness, an ode to feeling okayabout you, yourself, and everything."The full best of is available on this Spoty playlist. title: Steve Clarke  Bob Dylan  Dolly Parton  Here s the alternative  and real  honours list for 2020
story: The EastEnders actor spoke for many when he said the Covid catastrophe had exposed certain politiciansrsquo unfitness for office. ldquoWe must learn now that the people who went to Eton canrsquot run this country, he declared. ldquoWe need some working class people, people who have lived a real le, that are in touch with whatrsquos going on, to come to the front now and start getting involved with how this countryrsquos run. Handily for the star of Run for Your We, the Scottish Parliament elections take place next May. We know his family tree includes William the Conqueror and Henry III. Surely there must be a Scottish granny lurking somewhere in the branches She made history as the first woman and the first BAME person to become vice president-elect of the US, erased the pain of Hillary, annoyed the bejeezus out of Donald Trump, and did it all while rocking a white trouser suit like Travolta. Both she and -year-old president-elect Joe Biden were named Timersquos Person of the Year. So far, the pair have run their three-legged race well. The real marathon begins after the inauguration on January .: FM apologises for breaching Covid rulesLike Archie Gemmill heading for the Dutch goal, the Scotland manager juked round decades of humiliation, nutmegged the national tendency to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory, and took Scotland to its first major tournament in  years. He was an example to politicians everywhere of getting the job done, and he did so in a decidedly Scottish, understated way, a personality trail blazed by Andy Murray, Jock Stein and many another sporting great.When he warned in Subterranean Homesick Blues against following leaders , Dylan must have had a vision of . With the exception of New Zealandrsquos PM Jacinda Ardern, the worldrsquos premiers tried and failed to get ahead of the virus, and some of them paid the price . The first musician to win the Nobel Prize in Literature scored a hit by selling the rights to his songs, all of which he owned, for pound million, thus confirming he always has been the smartest guy in the music industryrsquos room.The professor of public health at the University of Edinburgh has shone a light through the fog of bluster generated by politicians. Cool, clear and articulate, she is an example to anyone who needs to communicate a message. Her florist has played a blinder, too, with prof Bauldrsquos ldquomedia cupboard never short of a nice vase of blooms.It had become an accepted fact of modern le that community wasnrsquot what it used to be , and that you and your neighbours were destined to be, at best, strangers on nodding terms. The pandemic changed that. We shopped for others, had socially distanced alfresco chats, and generally felt grateful for the people around us. Even her at number .It is not often a Labour MSP, or any MSP, finds themselves the subject of headlines in the New York Times. But on November ,  the Gray Lady reported that Scotland had become ldquothe first country in the world to make period products freely available to all who need them. After a four year campaign, Scottish Labourrsquos health spokesperson smashed taboos along the way with the Period Products Act. As Lennon said: ldquoThere has been a massive change in the way that periods are discussed in public le. A few years ago there had never been an open discussion of menstruation in the Holyrood chamber and now it is mainstream.The first lockdown began with Matt Hancock, Englandrsquos Health Secretary, telling footballers to lead by example and take a pay cut. Then along came a lad of  in a Man United shirt and showed Mr Hancock and the rest of the Cabinet how politics could and should be done. Marcus Rashford, the son of a single mother who worked full time yet couldnrsquot always afford to put food on the table, reckoned poor children going hungry in st century Britain was just plain wrong. His campaign to feed them year round manoeuvred the UK Government into a position where it could not say no. As one banner put it: ldquoRashford , Boris .How magnicent is the First Lady of country music  Let us count some of the ways. Besides continuing a career in which she has sold hundreds of millions of records, the now -year-old showed she had a keen eye for science and a heart for philanthropy when it was revealed she had given  million to the search for a Covid- vaccines. The product she had backed was among the successful ones. She may have famously said of herself that, ldquoIt takes a lot of money to look this cheap, but Miss Parton is four feet nine inches of sheer class.: Issue of the Day - Dolly PartonThe author took more than a decade to produce his debut novel, Shuggie Bain, but it arrived like a benign asteroid trailing showers of praise. Our own Teddy Jamieson described it as ldquoa fierce yet tender account of poverty, addiction and queerness in s Glasgow. Sighthill-born Stuart was only the second Scot to win the Booker after James Kelman with How Late it Was, How Late, in . While both were written in an authentic Scottish urban dialect, only Kelmanrsquos masterpiece had the literary establishment clutching its pearls in astonishment, bordering on outrage, that a working class voice was victorious. What a dference  years had made.: Douglas Stuart, The Herald Magazine interviewOur columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: love-hungry-dog-face-music-dance
story: He stood a little distance away as I was put into the waiting wheelchair to enter and a beaming Miriam threw him two biscuits. The box sitting on my table was the first thing I noticed.He arrives every morning and stares through the glass doors awaiting his biscuits. Nothing will entice him over the threshold.He does the same as night begins to fall, then s to the family who acquired him in the summer when I was in hospital.Perhaps Ceacutesar sent him a message that Irsquod be in need of a canine presence, however fleeting. Or like all dogs he instinctively knew there was a soul in need of comfort.He is all the dog I can cope with now for I am a poor, weak version of the woman I was, with not enough strength in me to even uncork a bottle of the wine I ordered for my . Now that IS a bloody tragedy.So, I was finally home after almost nine months away and although I would love to say I felt LMrsquos embrace ndash I felt nothing just the brooding silence when finally, alone.She has not softened or yielded towards me and I fear she only enjoys me in party mode.Only relaxes when within her walls is laughter and music or people loudly appreciating her rustic charms, admiring her ancient beams and strange quirks in the run of her floors, now just an added hazard for a Zimmer driver.But I am finally surrounded by my beloved books and pictures which provide a balm for the soul. They at least seem to welcome me back, appreciating my loving possessiveness and inner leaps of recognition warmed once more by a familiar, long known eye.My lovingly collected silver, including all photographs in ornate frames, are gone ndash taken to Piercersquos house in case of a break in so is my jewellery and the pierced holes in my lobes are closing up. Other things hersquos moved or re-arranged. Why ldquoI didnrsquot think yoursquod ever come back here. I thought yoursquod be coming to London, or something, are the unspoken words.Each morning Miriam arrives to open the house and shutters. I have not been well ndash cumulative after-effects of treatment ndash and Irsquom finding it hard to keep positive and hopeful.My thoughts are now darker and I struggle to find happiness in the awful maw of aloneness and loneliness, as the world itself does in this plague-ridden time.I start thinking of time left instead of time still left to be lived and then superstitiously rub, rub the negative away in case it taints and hinders me.Of course, Irsquom suffering from the loss of my safe place in the SSR. Suffering from the loss of kind, constant caring staff and experts, there at a buzzerrsquos touch.I miss the background noise in the corridors ndash the fast walk of a nurse going from room to room dispensing pills and reassurance the evening hello from the night staff and the last goodnight as you prepare for sleep.I miss le around me and these dark, uncaring sudden nights, and my early lock in gives no relief at all.I also miss my own bed and its well heated comfort, which I canrsquot risk because of a high step into the salon which leads to it.Irsquom in the flatter guest wing bedroom which is equally comfortable, but with its three exterior walls is a perfect summer room not a winter refuge.Occasionally I stand at the open glass doors looking out at the bleak winter scene, mist ridden for most of the morning.There has been little sun or blue skies to gladden the heart since my .Irsquom sorry. I know you donrsquot want to hear this from me ndash you want my lightness, my optimism, my determination hellip my hopeOh, itrsquos still there and will rise again, please God, but just now Irsquom struggling and frightened and thatrsquos all right too. Itrsquos allowed.But it cannot be indulged too far or I may not find my way back to enjoy the le that is still, still, within me..a privilege for as long as it is there.So, tomorrow, as I write, the day before Christmas Eve, I will be back in hospital for another session of immunotherapy, praying for calmer side effects later.Then on the th I will have the ten days of preventative brain radiation. Perhaps itrsquos no wonder all seems dark around me.But, but, but, I need to remember that all this has a point ndash to give me more time to let me savour the months left and be grateful for all thatrsquos gone before.Itrsquos the rhythm of le and I need to dance with its music until itrsquos over. And I have a visiting dog relying on breakfast biscuits.Meanwhile, my dear friends keep those prayers and wishes coming ndash they have their own ndash magic ndash music too.

title: dust-off-christmas-cobwebs-10-scotlands-best-post-indulgence-short-walks
story: Dust off the Christmas cobwebs with  of Scotland’s best post-indulgence short walksMaxwell Park in Pollokshields in the southside of Glasgow.Callander Crags, StirlingSituated behind the postcard Stirlingshire village of Callander, the Callander Crags is part of the rocky ledge that makes up the Highland Boundary Fault, where two continents collided almost  million years ago. Once you park up in the car park for the Bracklinn Falls itrsquos a short ndash but admittedly steep ndash climb to the summit of the Crags. The good news is that there are plenty of benches to stop atyou need a rest and once you make it to the top the views are more than worth it. You can see the snow-capped peak of Ben Ledi, arguably looking better in winter than summer, as well as a whole host of other hills, not to mention a great view back down over Callander itself. Once yoursquove taken the obligatory selfie at the summit yoursquoll want to escape the chilly wind and make your way back through the forest path. It can be slippery and steep in places so be sure to wear appropriate footwear and take your time. You can carry on back to the car park or take a detour into the village, with the cosy Deli Ecosse in Ancaster Square servingup much-needed takeaway coffeeand cake.Maxwell Park, PollokshieldsMost of those in the south side of Glasgow will flock to Pollok Park for their Boxing Day walk, descending on the paths near the Highland cattle and Pollok House. Butyou want an altogether more relaxed stroll, it would be well worth your while to try nearby Maxwell Park instead. Its location in the heart of leafy Pollokshields means that this park always feels like a quiet pocket of calm, even during busy periods. Therersquos a charming little duck pond to explore as well as some sections of woodland and garden, but it is small enough in size that it wonrsquot take long to get around. If, therefore, you are feeling a little more energetic, why not combine your loop of Maxwell Park with a walk to Queenrsquos Park in Shawlands  Therersquos no shortage of coffee shops in the streets in-between the two parks where you can pick up a drink to warm you up.River Ness and Ness Islands, InvernessIt might run through the heart of the city, but the River Ness is always a good option for a peaceful walk. Its accessible riverside path makes it popular with cyclists and joggers but it rarely gets too busy, particularlyyou head further along the river towards the Ness Islands. These form a three-mile routeyou loop around themwith picturesque Victorian suspension bridges that you cross to get there. Popular with picnickers in the summer, the islands are just as worthy of a visit in winter, where you can spot wildle among the trees, take a rest on one of the many benches and snap a picture with Inverness Castle in the background. If you are feeling particularly fit you can keep going beyond the river path towards the Great Glen Way, or along the Caledonian Canal.Muasdale Beach, Kintyre, Argyll and ButeHeading to the beach isnrsquot an obvious choice when the weather is cold and the wind is biting. But this picture-perfect Kintyre beach offers panoramic views of Islay and Jura, with drtwood, pebbles and rockpools lining the shore. It is long and narrow, perfect for a short stroll, but you can continue on further along the route of the Kintyre Wayyou feel up to it.Falls of Foyers, Foyers, near Fort AugustusTo get to the viewpoint of the magical Falls of Foyers, the walk is entirely leisurely. You can stroll down the steps to get thereto then enjoy wonderful views of the water tumbling down from above, before venturing down to the lower viewpoint for a dferent perspective. But while it is a short distance, thejourney back up all those stairs is tough on even the fittest of walkers, so stop as many times as you need to in order to catch your breath. It can be slippery too, especially at this time of year, so wear sensible footwear and tread carefully.Whitelee Windfarm, EagleshamWhitelee Windfarm, the largest onshore windfarm in the UK, has become steadily more popular with visitors since it first opened a decade ago. Cyclists frequent its flat paths and mountain biking trails while dog owners and horse riders appreciate the swathes of open moorland thatrsquos on offer. And for those looking for an easy post-Christmas walk, it is an ideal place to go. You can park up near the visitor centreand then head out towards the foot of the first turbine ndash which is quite awe-inducing to stand underneath. From there, therersquos a iety of paths and routes that you can take, walking as far as you feel like, with the loop up to the Blackwood Hill Viewpoint a particularly good option. Therersquos a brief uphill climb, but you will be rewarded with views out to Arran and Ailsa Craig on a clear day.Portencross, North AyrshireTherersquos nothing quite like a sea breeze to shake you out of a hangover. But while Troon and Prestwick might be the more popular options for a seaside walk, those in the know would tell you that it is the small hamlet of Portencross that offers some of the best views in Ayrshire. Its proximity to Arran means it has an unrivalled outlook over the sea to the island, which looks particularly majestic as the sun is going down. Therersquos a car park in Portencross which makes a good starting point for a stroll: from there, head along towards the tiny Portencross castle ndash which had close links with King Robert II ndash before stopping off at the pier which offers wonderful views out to sea and back towards the village. Then simply follow the coastal path as far as you wish, with ious picnic benches dotted along the seafrontyou want to brave the wind while having a sit down.Chatelherault Country Park, HamiltonThe very French name of this Lanarkshire park is owed to Mary Queen of Scots. Duc de Chacirctelleraultwas the title given to James Hamilton, nd Earl of Arran, for his part in arranging the marriage of Mary to the young French prince Francis. The park was the main residence of the Dukes of Hamilton for decades, and although the grand Hamilton Palace has since been demolished their extravagant hunting lodge remains. Modern visitors can admire this wonderful building, located right beside the car park, before wandering further into the park for as long a walk as you feel able for. Therersquos  acres of countryside and woodland and over  miles of routed pathways to explore ndash butyou are nursing a sore head you can always just wander around the outside of the lodge and then head back to the car.Alva Glen, AlloaIt only takes an hour to complete, but the walk round Alva Glen packs in woodland, waterfalls, gorges, caves and a spectacular view out across the Clackmannanshire countryside. Simply start at the signposted Alva Glen car park and head up through the woodland to reach the first of several waterfalls. Soon the path begins to climb steeply , with bridges leading up over the gorge and eventually offering a sublime view out over the glen below. Once you reach the Smugglerrsquos Cave, retrace your steps back to the start.Duchess Wood, HelensburghJust a short walk from the centre of Helensburgh lies the Duchess Wood. It is large enough to feel like you have escaped civilisation, but short enough that you can loop around it in less than an hour. Dogs will love running around and exploring the forest, while kids can enjoy spotting squirrels and birds between the trees.

title: letters-can-anyone-explain-postal-service-getting-worse
story: Four of my long-term friends from North and South Lanarkshire posted Christmas cards to me around two weeks ago. My sister and niece in Canada mailed theirs at the beginning of December and my son, who lives in Baden Wurtemberg in Germany, posted his on December . I have, as yet, received none of them. My son also ordered, on the same date, a present online to be delivered to me and was told it was guaranteed to be received before the th. The company has now told him it cannot honour its original guarantee.I havent been able to meet my old friends for months now as we are sticking to the rules and Im missing contact with them of any kind other than a WhatsApp group but, and I cant explain why, receiving a written note from them seems more personal. Maybe Im just old fashioned. My son and his girlfriend are of course also unable to come home for Christmas as they had planned. I do feel very grateful and lucky for the friends I have made here since moving more than two years ago and to my daughter, her husband and my granddaughter who now live nearby.We have an excellent regular postman in our street who knows nearly everyone so Im certain the fault is not his. but as the costs of postage rise but the service worsens you have to wonder who is responsible Id be interested to hear of any other of your readers had experienced similar problems.Happy Christmas to all anyway.Margaret Thomson, Boness.STURGEON IS SUCH A CARDNO doubt along with several hundred thousand other Scots on Monday , I received a ldquoSeasonrsquos Greetings card from the Scottish Government. Unfortunately, as the rules it gives for meetings from December - were cancelled last Saturday, it was out-of-date on receipt, though still in part valid.But worse, it inevitably includes a signed missive from the First Minister, thanking me for ldquoall that you have done over the past  months to keep yourself and others safe and saying ldquoI am hugely appreciative of all your sacrices ndash on both of which she writes from a position of total ignorance.Finally, typically putting herself in the forefront, she writes: ldquoI and the Scottish Government Shielding team wish youhellip... Was she not taught at school that courtesy requires us to place the other party first in such sentences John Birkett, St Andrews.REPLACE SENTIMENTALITY WITH COMPASSIONEVERY day we hear of the gross inequalities which blight our humanity and which ought to challenge us to question our attitudes towards our fellow human beings. In this context may I suggest that Christmas is the time to ask ourselves what is the real signicance of the man born two millennia ago in Palestine Jesus reveals to us that what makes us truly human is a radical love for all others without exception. He was empowered by his closeness to his God, a God who is Love, a Love which is so radical, so all-encompassing that it must influence every aspect of the lives of those who take Jesus and his God seriously: personal, communal and political, politics being the only way to remove the structural injustices which are at the root of the aforementioned inequalities.My conclusion  It is time to eliminate both consumerism and sentimentality from Christmas and replace them with a compassion for and solidarity with those who are oppressed and voiceless, who experience poverty, hunger, violence, rejection and abuse because they are dferent.John Milne, Uddingston.MISSING A HOLIDAY IS NO TRAGEDYIS Rosemary Goringliving on a dferent planet to the rest of us  At a time when the nation is facing the probability of another lockdown which will plunge retail, tourism, hospitality, the arts, and countless iniduals into financial meltdown, she shares her desolation about being unable to spend Christmas in Florence.The day after reports reveal alarming statistics concerning the rise in homelessness due to Covid-, Ms Goring is devastated at not being able to go to Edinburgh to see the festive lights. While the Salvation Army and a legion of volunteers take food to thousands of lorry drivers trapped in Dover, she regales us with tales of "wolfing down cannoli, panettone and chou pastries" and having the perfect Christmas Eve dinner blighted by American students.Am I missing something  Is this satire  Enough of this self-indulgent whining from a journalist who equates misery with the cancellation of a holiday. Go and spend Christmas Day in a homeless shelter, Ms Goring, or a food bank, and experience the real world. Then write about that.Grace Barnes, Lerwick.LETS BRUSH UP ON THE SPROUTSI AM obliged to Alan Susskindfor advising that Brussels sprouts are great for the libido, and would be grateful for further advice regarding the dosage and how often.I admit to previous disappointment with similar claims for oysters when once I splashed out on six and found that two of them didnrsquot work.R Russell Smith, Largs.

title: opinion-brian-beacoms-week-priti-patel
story: As for the grilling Irsquove been getting about schools re-opening  I canrsquot tell you about all pupils because, obviously, schools operate dferently across the country. And I certainly canrsquot tell Nicola what to do. I fear she could be a bigger bully than me. . Donrsquot give me that disdainful look.Yes, the November enquiry deemed Irsquod breached the ministerial code again. But then ministerial codes are like the Enigma. Theyrsquore there to be broken! At least the last time I broke ministerial protocol I was clever enough to be tanking a lovely pound, an hour. I know there was an alleged conflict of interests Home Secretary takes cash from global communications firm that supplies products and services to the UK Government. But that wasnrsquot the case at all. There is no conflict for me when cash is involved. And the media love to take my comments out of context. Like the time I said that the economic impact of a no-deal Brexit on the Republic of Ireland could encourage the EU to drop the backstop.Well, some people actually took that at face value. And just because in one interview I repeatedly confused lsquocounter-terrorismrsquo with lsquoterrorismrsquo some label me lsquoPriti Vacant.rsquo Easy mistake to make, Mister! Sure, critics like to say I only got into politics because Dave had me fast-tracked into a safe seat, to widen the party demographic. Well, that may be true, but Irsquove always been an opportunist.They forget I was happy to work for a PR company with a contract with British American Tobacco and a remit to convince African kids to start puffinrsquo like lab beagles. I wasnrsquot vague either at the time when I was up for capital punishment, and down on the idea of same-sex marriages.Irsquove kicked out at Windrush and Extinction Rebellion. And I was as clear as the space between Dominic Raabrsquos ears when I once said I wasnrsquot strictly in favour of the rule of law ndash which I suppose as Home Secretary is a bit like Craig Revel Horwood saying itrsquos ok for Strictly contestants to make up the moves as they go along. But we need a bit of freestyle thinking in this world donrsquot we Sure, Theresa resigned me as International Development Secretary after the time I holidayed in Isreal and instead of taking little Freddie to the waterparks in Eilat I took  off-the-book meetings with dignitaries such as Benjamin Netanyahu. But you can have a lot of fun in the Golan Heights too you know. But Irsquom back, under Boris, so to speak. And as protected as a white tiger. So stop your whinging Scotland and drink your Buckfast."Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

story: But increasing alarm over not one, but two, highly contagious iant strains of the new coronavirus circulating in the UK has changed that.Now I find it dficult to imagine that we are facing anything  as we prepare to enter the new year.If the experience of South Africa and south-east England is anything to go by, softer circuit break restrictions will not be enough.We may even need something tougher than we had in March.A briefing by scientists on the UKrsquos NERVTAGnoted that the UK iant ldquohas demonstrated exponential growth during a period when national lockdown measures were in place.: % of Covid infections in Scotland linked to UK iant strainContaining the spread of this strain will require extremely high compliance with stay-at-home rules and self-isolation in particular - something which has been woeful in the UK until now.In France, anyone leaving their homes during lockdown must complete attestationforms stating their reasons for going out - for example, essential work, collecting children from schools, picking up medicines. Residents caught outside without a valid reason or straying further than the permitted kilometrefrom their property have been hit with eurofines.In Greece, citizens must text their name, address and reason for wishing to leave their house to a five-digit government number to request permission to go out.This might seem anathema to le in the UK, but can it be a coincidence that in the past few days both Nicola Sturgeonand UK Health Secretary Matt Hancockhave raised the prospect of legal enforcements for both " alt"HeraldScotland: Cases of coronavirus have been rising in the south and east of England, where the mutant strain is concentrated, but falling in other regions " class"editor-image"Cases of coronavirus have been rising in the south and east of England, where the mutant strain is concentrated, but falling in other regions We are in a perilous situation - undoubtedly the worst since the virus first arrived in the UK - and while the prospect of mass vaccination gives us hope, we have a long way to go, at least until mid-, before substantial population coverage is likely to be achieved.If these iants take hold as experts fear they could, we must think seriously about better practical and financial support to enable people to self-isolate, both in the form of of quarantine hotels and making isolation payments either more generous for the low-paid or simply easier to access .So what do we know so far about these iants which have cancelled Christmas and look set to overshadow the new year The UK iant, known as VUI  is characterised by a total of  mutations compared to the original Wuhan cluster -  of which appear to have occurred in at once.: We could have had a normal Christmas - but the time to achieve it was JulyThe leading theory for now - although investigations are ongoing - is that the iant first evolved in September in a patient, possibly in the Kent area, who was sick with the infection for a long time, maximising the opportunity for mutations.These are naturally lsquocopying errorsrsquo which occur at a molecular level as the virus replicates in its human hosts and spreads. Think of it like a -page book where every so often a couple of letters randomly switch places as new copies are rushed off the press.Occasionally one of these mutations will confer a lsquoselective advantagersquo - such as making a virus more transmissible. As a general rule in virology, however, the more infectious a virus becomes the more its lethality dwindles.For example, the original  SARS killed around  per cent of people who caught it compared to the new SARS-CoV- version, which has an estimated case-fatality rate somewhere in the region of .-% . But SARS also ran out of steam and no case has been detected anywhere in the world since .A virusrsquo only goal is to be passed on and multiply, which is better achieved by being highly contagious - but not overly deadly.It remains to be seen of course whether this will turn out to be the case for the UK iant, which is estimated to be % more transmissible and as of mid-December was accounting for around % of all new cases in London.The UK and South Africa have experienced a huge surge in cases since the beginning of DecemberThere has been a suggestion that the iant may be more infectious in children after NERVTAG member Professor Neil Ferguson told journalists that the number of cases of the new iant detected in under-s is ldquosignicantly higher ldquothan other strains, but there is currently no published evidence to demonstrate that.: If only taking back control had applied to our borders in a pandemicThe South African mutation, dubbed .YV, has been detected in two locations in Britain - in London and the north-west of England. It makes up around % of the new cases in South Africa, which is currently in the midst of its summer when the disease should have been easier to control.On Wednesday, South Africarsquos Health Minister Dr Zweli Mkhize warned that the ldquorate of spread is much faster than the first wave and we will surpass the peak of the first wave in the coming days.In Scotland positive Covid cases have been rising again since early DecemberWorryingly for the UK, Dr Mkhize has suggested the disease could actually be more lethal in young people, saying that doctors ldquoare seeing a larger proportion of younger patients with no co-morbidities presenting with critical illness.However, it is also true that young people may be getting sick because many more of them are getting infected this time around, with students and teenagers blamed for super-spreading the virus with post-exam parties.The South African iant has more mutations, three of which might affect vaccine efficacy, though this could be rectiednecessary.In the meantime, standard measures - hand-washing, social distancing, and self-isolation - remain our best defence against transmission. But compliance will be more important than ever.

title: coronavirus-call-reform-immigration-rules
story: Campaigners have warned first-year students will not qualy for pre-settled statusthey arrive after the end of the transition period on December  ndash even though they may have opted to study online or could not move to the UK because of Covid- restrictions.This would mean they will need to apply for a student visa when coming here in  to continue their studies, hitting them with application costs of pound and pound a year in health charges.Mantas Gudelis, who started a biochemistry degree at Edinburgh University in September and is studying at home in Lithuania, previously told : ldquoThe health surcharge over four years is pound, and for my family that is a lot of money... The system should allow us to come because this is not our fault.Now the Scottish Government has written to Kevin Foster, UK Minister for Future Borders and Immigration, to ask that the rules be amended so all EU students who enrolled at a Scottish higher education institution in the - academic year, but were unable to travel due to Covid, are deemed to have met residency requirements when applying to the Settlement Scheme.This would be the case eventhey arrive after December .The letter was written by former migration minister Ben Macpherson ndash announced as Minister for Rural Affairs and the Natural Environment in a recent reshuffle ndash and will be taken forward by Europe Minister Jenny Gilruth.It states: ldquoThe pandemic has meant that many universities and colleges have provided students with the opportunity to study remotely at home. A signicant number of EU students have taken up this option, likely as a consequence of electing not to travel or because they are not allowed to leave their country of origin.ldquoAs a result, some students who were scheduled to arrive in the UK to commence their studies in  will not arrive until  and, therefore, do not comply with the EU Settlement Scheme because they will not be living here by the end of .ldquoThis means they will need to apply for a student visa... Students in this position will be faced with visa application costs of pound and an annual health charge of pound.The letter continues: ldquoI am aware of a number of cases of students at Scottish universities, but currently studying remotely, who have been advised by the Home Office that they will incur the above coststhey wish to come to the UK from .ldquoI am therefore writing to ask you to amend the Immigration Rules. All EU students who enrolled at a Scottish higher education institute in the academic year - but were unable to travel here due to Covid restrictions should be deemed to have met the residency requirements when applying to the EU Settlement Scheme, eventhey arrive here after  December .The letter has received backing from university representatives.ldquoWe support the ask made by the Scottish Government, said a spokesman for Universities Scotland.ldquoMore costs are a further barrier for EU students to come and study in Scotland. We hope the UK Government will recognise the extraordinary circumstances that many EU students find themselves in and make an exception.NUS Scotland President Matt Crilly said: ldquoWe have already called for an extension to the eligibility criteria for the EU Settlement Scheme until the end of the next academic year.
